name: Chuanqing Pu
intro: I am currently a PhD candidate specializing in probabilistic forecasting and uncertainty-aware/data-driven optimization for power systems. I am also passionate about data engineering, especially skilled in time-series forecasting and optimization modeling. I also maintain a personal Blog and GitHub repositories where I share insights and projects in data science.
Research Interests: Time Series Forecasting (Renewable Energy, Electricity Price, Load)

Research Experience.title: Zero-shot Photovoltaic Power Nowcasting via Vision–Language Models
Research Experience.abstract: Despite the remarkable progress of deep learning–based methods for photovoltaic (PV) power forecasting, their fundamental limitation lies in a strong reliance on site-specific historical data for end-to-end customized training. Newly commissioned PV plants often lack sufficient operational records, rendering reliable forecasting infeasible. PV nowcasting is largely determined by the structure, boundaries, and evolution of cloud fields, which are observable from satellite imagery and exhibit shared visual semantics across regions and satellite products. We formalize cold-start PV nowcasting as a visual-driven zero-shot trajectory forecasting problem under out-of-distribution (OOD) conditions. We propose a vision–language model (VLM)–conditioned retrieval-augmented framework that uses semantics as a bridge for cross-domain generalization and estimates future PV power trajectories via local conditional expectation in the learned representation space.

Research Experience.title: Predict-then-Optimize for Seaport Power-Logistics Scheduling: Generalization across Varying Tasks Stream
Research Experience.abstract: Decision-focused learning aligns the training of forecasting models with downstream decision outcomes. However, this end-to-end design inherently restricts the value of forecasting models to only a specific task structure, and thus generalize poorly to evolving tasks. We address this gap with a decision-focused continual learning framework that adapts online to a stream of scheduling tasks. Specifically, we introduce Fisher information based regularization to enhance cross-task generalization by preserving parameters critical to prior tasks. A differentiable convex surrogate is also developed to stabilize gradient backpropagation. The proposed approach enables learning a decision-aligned forecasting model across a varying tasks stream with a sustainable long-term computational burden.
Research Experience.authors: Chuanqing Pu, Feilong Fan, Nengling Tai, Yan Xu, Wentao Huang, Honglin Wen

Research Experience.title: A Hybrid Strategy for Probabilistic Forecasting and Trading of Aggregated Wind-Solar Power: Design and Analysis in HEFTCom2024
Research Experience.abstract: This paper presents the solution of team GEB, which ranked 1st among student teams in the IEEE Hybrid Energy Forecasting and Trading Competition 2024 (HEFTCom2024). The solution provides accurate probabilistic forecasts for a wind-solar hybrid system, and achieves substantial trading revenue in the day-ahead electricity market. Code for all mentioned methods is available at https://github.com/BigdogManLuo/HEFTcom24, for reproduction and further research in both industry and academia.
Research Experience.authors: Chuanqing Pu, Feilong Fan, Nengling Tai, Songyuan Liu, Jinming Yu

Research Experience.title: Distributed Stochastic Operation of Low-Carbon Port Energy-Logistics Systems via Learning to Warm-Start
Research Experience.abstract: We propose a fast distributed scheduling framework that decomposes the centralized energy-logistics scheduling problem into iterative subproblems via ADMM, and introduces a learning-based warm start to accelerate convergence while preserving optimality. Our method reduces the computational time by more than 50% compared to GUROBI and MOSEK solvers.
Research Experience.authors: Feilong Fan, Chuanqing Pu, Nengling Tai, Jiayi Luo, Zhanpeng Chen, Xipeng Zhang

Research Experience.title: Transmission Power-oriented Forecasting towards Stability-Constrained Operation of Renewable Energy Power Plants with Energy Storages
Research Experience.abstract: This work proposes a forecasting method for renewable energy power plants with energy storage, explicitly accounting for grid-stability issues rather than only minimizing statistical errors. We embed the REPP operational model into the forecasting loss to quantify how forecast errors affect deliverable transmission power, and develop an implicit-differentiation training algorithm to enable end-to-end backpropagation.

Data Engineering Experience.name: IEEE Hybrid Energy Forecasting and Trading Competition (HEFTCom24)
Data Engineering Experience.description: During the first year of my Ph.D., I participated in the IEEE HEFTCom24 competition, which focuses on developing efficient hybrid wind–solar power forecasting and trading strategies to address the volatility and uncertainty of renewable generation. Our team developed multiple approaches, including multi-source NWP stacking for probabilistic forecasting, Quantile-LASSO–based online post-processing, probability density aggregation, and a stochastic trading strategy under electricity price uncertainty. Ultimately, we achieved the lowest average pinball loss and the highest trading profit, earning the “Best Student Team (1st Place)” award. We were also invited to present our work at ISF 2024, and submitted a paper detailing our methodology to the International Journal of Forecasting.

Data Engineering Experience.name: THS Forecasting Hackathon 2025
Data Engineering Experience.description: I participated in the forecasting hackathon organized by the International Institute of Forecasters (IIF) at ISF 2025. This was an in-person, time-limited coding competition focused on forecasting quarterly inbound tourism arrivals to Hong Kong and Macao for 2023–2025. By applying time-series analysis and machine learning techniques, I achieved 1st place with the lowest MAE.

Data Engineering Experience.name: Kaggle - Hull Tactical Market Prediction
Data Engineering Experience.description: This was a global quantitative trading competition with over 5,000 participants. Contestants were required to predict the daily excess returns of S&P 500 constituents and make position-scaling decisions to maximize the Sharpe ratio. I developed a solution that combines probabilistic forecasting with uncertainty-aware optimization: I estimated CVaR via dense quantile regression, and formulated a position optimization model by deriving the one-step loss of the scoring rule. In an offline, leakage-free walk-forward evaluation, my model achieved an average Sharpe ratio of 1.33 across all folds (variance 0.9), exceeding the 15% market Sharpe benchmark.

Data Engineering Experience.name: “TI Cup” National Undergraduate Electronic Design Competition
Data Engineering Experience.description: During my junior year, I participated in the 2021 “TI Cup” National Undergraduate Electronic Design Contest and won the National First Prize. The competition required designing and implementing DSP-based control algorithms for a three-phase inverter and rectifier. I led the development of the algorithmic modules, including three-/single-phase PLL, PID and PR controllers, and dq/αβ coordinate transformations, and delivered the full engineering workflow—from algorithm design to PCB implementation and experimental validation.

Data Engineering Experience.name: “PowerFlower”: A Mini-Software for Power Flow Calculations
Data Engineering Experience.description: During my junior year, I developed a mini software called PowerFlower for power flow calculations. The software was written in MATLAB scripts and used App Designer to create a graphical interface. PowerFlower supports various power flow calculation methods, including the Newton-Raphson method, PQ decomposition method, and batch power flow analysis. Users can easily input system data, run power flow calculations, and view results graphically.
